body.p: When you need to bring back your cloud and restart services, whether because you intentionally powered down or because you lost power, follow the steps here to safely restart your cloud. If you also lost data, config, or everything, visit the backup and restore pages first at Backing up and Restoring Your Data.

ol.li: If you are shutting down the cluster, in scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible run hlm-stop. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-stop.yml
If you are already down and without power, then run bm-power-up to power up your nodescd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts bm-power-up.yml
Next, run hlm-start cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-start.yml
If RabbitMQ fails, execute the steps in the following document to safely restart it: Recover RabbitMQ after Outage or Node Restart
Next, you can check the status of HPE Helion OpenStack services: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-status.yml
If any services did not start properly, see Starting and Stopping Services
If any nodes fail, see the node maintenance documents: Node Maintenance
If necessary, run hlm-start again cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-start.yml
You may then check the status of all services:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-status.yml
